From Wiktionary, the free dictionary

Bourguignon

[edit]

Etymology 1

[edit]

From Old French vouivre, Latin vipera.

Noun

[edit]

vivre m (plural vivres)

  1. a mythical creature similar to a wyvern living in different parts of Burgundy (especially in Tonnerre)
  2. any type of snake
Alternative forms
[edit]
  • vouivre
  • guivre

Etymology 2

[edit]

From Old French vivre, from Latin vivere.

Verb

[edit]

vivre

  1. to live
    joie de vivre
    joy of living
Conjugation
[edit]
      Conjugation in Bourguignon

gerund vivant
auxiliary aivoi

singular vicu vicue

1st person 2nd person 3rd person 1st person 2nd person 3rd person

present vis vis vit vivons vivez vivant
imperfect vivoos vivoos vivoot viveins viveins viveint

future vivré vivrés vivré vivrons vivrez vivront
conditional vivroos vivroos vivroot vivreins vivreins vivreint
subjunctive que je (j') / qu'i* que tu (t') qu'ai (el), qu'ale que je (j') / qu'i* que vos qu'ai (el), qu'ales
present vive vives vive viveins viveins viveint
imperfect vicquisse vicquisses vicquisse vicquisseins vicquisseins vicquisseint
imperative — tu — je (j') / i* vos —
present vis vivons vivez
* je is found in Central and Eastern Burgundy, i is found in the Morvan and partially throughout the whole region
Related terms
[edit]
  • vivant
  • vivifiai

Franco-Provençal

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

Inherited from Latin vīvere.

Verb

[edit]

vivre (ORB, broad)

  1. to live
    Antonym: morir

Conjugation

[edit]
    Conjugation of vivre
simple compound

French

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

Inherited from Middle French vivre, from Old French vivre, from Latin vīvere, from Proto-Italic *gʷīwō, from Proto-Indo-European *gʷíh₃weti (“to live, be alive”). Forms in véc- originate from Latin irregular perfect stem vīx- (vīxī, vīxistī, ...) undergoing metathesis and shortening to *vĭsc-.

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • IPA(key): /vivʁ/
  • Rhymes: -ivʁ
  • Audio:(file)
  • Audio (Switzerland (Valais)):(file)
  • Audio (France (Paris)):(file)
  • Audio (France (Toulouse)):(file)
  • Audio (France (Vosges)):(file)
  • Audio (France):(file)
  • Audio (France (Grenoble)):(file)
  • Audio (France (Brétigny-sur-Orge)):(file)
  • Audio (France (Vosges)):(file)
  • Audio (France (Hérault)):(file)
  • Audio (France (Lyon)):(file)
  • Audio (France (Massy)):(file)
  • Audio (France (Somain)):(file)

Verb

[edit]

vivre

  1. to live
    Antonym: mourir
    vivre comme un roi ― live like a king
  2. to experience

1 The French gerund is usable only with the preposition en.
2 In less formal writing or speech, these tenses may be found to have been replaced in the following way:
past historic → present perfect
past anterior → pluperfect
imperfect subjunctive → present subjunctive
pluperfect subjunctive → past subjunctive

(Christopher Kendris [1995], Master the Basics: French, pp. 77, 78, 79, 81).

Derived terms

[edit]
  • âme qui vive
  • art de vivre
  • faire bon vivre
  • ils vécurent heureux et eurent beaucoup d'enfants
  • joie de vivre
  • l'espoir fait vivre
  • on ne vit qu'une fois
  • pour vivre heureux, vivons cachés
  • qui vit par l'épée périra par l'épée
  • qui vivra verra
  • sentir le vécu
  • sur le qui-vive
  • vivre au-dessus de ses moyens
  • vivre aux crochets de
  • vivre avec son temps
  • vivre d'amour et d'eau fraiche
  • vivre dans une grotte
  • vivre en grand seigneur
  • vivre sa vie

Related terms

[edit]
  • vif
  • vivace
  • vivement
  • vivifier
  • vivisection

Further reading

[edit]
  • “vivre”, in Trésor de la langue française informatisé [Digitized Treasury of the French Language], 2012.

Middle French

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

From Old French vivre, from Latin vīvere.

Verb

[edit]

vivre

  1. to live

Descendants

[edit]
  • French: vivre

Norman

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

From Old French vivre, from Latin vīvō, vīvere, from Proto-Indo-European *gʷíh₃weti (“to live, be alive”).

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • Audio (Jersey):(file)

Verb

[edit]

vivre

  1. (Jersey) to live
    • 1903, Edgar MacCulloch, “Proverbs, Weather Sayings, etc.”, in Guernsey Folk Lore‎[1], page 542:
      I' vit d'amour et de belles chànsons—coum' les alouettes de roques.
      He lives on love and fine songs—as larks do on stones.

Old French

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

From Latin vīvere.

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • IPA(key): /ˈvivɾə/

Verb

[edit]

vivre

  1. to live

Conjugation

[edit]

This verb conjugates as a third-group verb. This verb has irregularities in its conjugation. Old French conjugation varies significantly by date and by region. The following conjugation should be treated as a guide.

    Conjugation of vivre (see also Appendix:Old French verbs)
simple compound
infinitive vivre avoir vescu
gerund en vivant gerund of avoir + past participle
present participle vivant
past participle vescu
person singular plural
first second third first second third
indicative jo tu il nos vos il
simple
tenses 		present vif vis vit vivons vivez vivent
imperfect vivoie, viveie vivoies, viveies vivoit, viveit viviiens, viviens viviiez, viviez vivoient, viveient
preterite vesqui vesquis vesquié vesquimes vesquistes vesquierent
future vivrai vivras vivra vivrons vivroiz, vivreiz, vivrez vivront
conditional vivroie, vivreie vivroies, vivreies vivroit, vivreit vivriiens, vivriens vivriiez, vivriez vivroient, vivreient
compound
tenses 		present perfect present tense of avoir + past participle
pluperfect imperfect tense of avoir + past participle
past anterior preterite tense of avoir + past participle
future perfect future tense of avoir + past participle
conditional perfect conditional tense of avoir + past participle
subjunctive que jo que tu qu’il que nos que vos qu’il
simple
tenses 		present vive vives vive vivons vivez vivent
imperfect vesquisse vesquisses vesquist vesquissons, vesquissiens vesquissoiz, vesquissez, vesquissiez vesquissent
compound
tenses 		past present subjunctive of avoir + past participle
pluperfect imperfect subjunctive of avoir + past participle
imperative – tu – nos vos –
— vif — vivons vivez —

Antonyms

[edit]
  • morir

Descendants

[edit]
  • Bourguignon: vivre
  • Middle French: vivre
    • French: vivre
  • Franc-Comtois: vétche
  • Norman: vivre (Jersey)
